facts.fact: Kaspa’s architecture and execution, particularly by the Crescendo development team, achieves a 6000x improvement over Satoshi Nakamoto's original Bitcoin protocol while retaining the same trust model.
facts.context: Demonstrates a significant technical advancement over the original Bitcoin protocol, while upholding decentralized, trustless security assumptions.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Kaspa’s network structure remains center-less with network control delegated to an anonymous, competing set of miners.
facts.context: Confirms adherence to a decentralized mining consensus, aligning with principles similar to those of Bitcoin.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The Kaspa project emphasizes being "culturally open-source, practically center-less, constitutionally principled" as core to unlocking and recognizing its value.
facts.context: Highlights the project's philosophy regarding community-driven, decentralized governance, which could influence development and adoption.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The future arrival of ASICs is anticipated for Kaspa mining, which will shift the ecosystem from primarily GPU mining to more capital expenditure (CapEx)-heavy operations.
facts.context: The transition to ASICs is expected to promote network maturity and enhance mining efficiency.

facts.fact: As of the article's writing, approximately 5.3% of the Kaspa network’s hash rate is “NiceHash-able,” meaning it can be rented via hashpower marketplaces like NiceHash.
facts.context: A lower NiceHash-able percentage indicates a less “liquid” market for hashpower rental, making the network more resistant to inexpensive 51% attacks.

facts.fact: CapEx-heavy mining (i.e., ASIC-based mining) is considered more energy efficient in that a smaller fraction of the network’s security budget is expended per block compared to GPU/OpEx-heavy models.
facts.context: Higher energy efficiency is increasingly important for Kaspa’s future, especially as block rewards diminish and for addressing concerns over mining-related waste.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s consensus layer is being optimized primarily for speed of confirmation, with secondary focuses on throughput capacity, decentralization, and downstream considerations like MEV (Miner Extractable Value) resistance.
facts.context: Speed of confirmation is a critical performance metric and a core goal of Kaspa’s technological design.

facts.fact: Fast confirmation speeds in Kaspa’s protocol depend on an “illiquid” mining market, meaning it is difficult for attackers to temporarily rent significant hash power and execute 51% attacks.
facts.context: Illiquidity increases network security and reduces vulnerability to attacks facilitated by hashpower rental.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT (DK) is a protocol developed by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Sutton, released as an academic effort tied to the Kaspa project, and its main development tasks are outlined in KIP #2.
facts.context: DK is an important consensus extension for Kaspa, and KIP #2 specifies remaining tasks needed for its production-readiness.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT implementation for Kaspa is being proposed for funding via a community grant of 70 million KAS, equivalent to approximately 0.5% of the circulating supply.
facts.context: The grant mechanism is the prevailing custom for funding major Kaspa development, as with a previous 100 MKAS grant (~1% supply).

facts.fact: The previous community-funded Kaspa development grant was 100 million KAS, about 1% of the token’s circulating supply at the time.
facts.context: Indicates community practice and precedent for denominating development grants in KAS tokens rather than fiat.

facts.fact: The implementation of DAGKNIGHT on Kaspa will proceed regardless of whether the grant is accepted, though timelines would be unspecified and progress may be slower without incentive.
facts.context: Suggests ongoing commitment to DK integration, but highlights grant’s role in prioritizing and resourcing work.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT is characterized as infrastructure-level development for Kaspa, not involving application-layer (e.g., smart contract) features.
facts.context: Clarifies that DK’s impact is primarily to Kaspa’s consensus/infrastructure, not to user-facing dApps or smart contracts.

facts.fact: KIP #2 provides a detailed list of technical tasks and requirements necessary to complete DAGKNIGHT’s implementation within Kaspa.
facts.context: Specifies a concrete source (https://github.com/kaspanet/kips/blob/master/kip-0002.md) for tracking DK development progress and required work.

facts.fact: The DAGKNIGHT (DK) protocol was published by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Michal Sutton as a proof-of-work consensus protocol responsive to actual adversarial network latency while being resilient to 49% byzantine attackers.
facts.context: DK is, to the authors’ knowledge, the first PoW protocol with these properties, improving security and latency responsiveness compared to prior protocols.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT enables high blocks-per-second (bps) rates with much faster confirmation times than previous protocols like GHOSTDAG.
facts.context: High bps with fast confirmations means increased throughput without the compromise on confirmation speed, significant for scaling performance.

facts.fact: Further development on DAGKNIGHT is required for Kaspa, including completing the theoretical proof section, preparing the protocol for peer-review, devising efficient algorithms, and adapting to requirements such as minting, difficulty adjustment, and pruning.
facts.context: These steps are necessary for practical implementation in a live cryptocurrency system; DK is not yet production-ready.

facts.fact: Increasing bps rates indefinitely under DK does not always reduce confirmation times because higher rates increase DAG width and block header size, potentially increasing relative latency.
facts.context: There's a trade-off between bps rate and confirmation time due to network and protocol-level constraints.

facts.fact: One research direction enabled by DK is supporting "flexcaps," i.e., blocks of different sizes and difficulties, originally proposed for Bitcoin; this helps allow higher throughput during peak demand and manage resource consumption better.
facts.context: Flexcaps could allow more flexible, scalable network throughput, but require a consensus protocol like DK that tolerates variable DAG width.

facts.fact: DK protocol uniquely operates without needing to predefine or strictly bound the DAG width and can handle fluctuating DAG width over short timespans.
facts.context: This feature is essential for dynamic throughput and block size adaptation, which is not possible in some other protocols.

facts.fact: DK could enable stealth transactions (stealth txns) leveraging asynchrony from high bps to protect users from Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) attacks, particularly when smart contracts are implemented in Kaspa.
facts.context: This offers a new privacy and anti-MEV mechanism that is tightly coupled to DK's consensus properties.

facts.fact: DK’s consensus properties could facilitate richer transaction fee mechanisms, as many miners can create blocks in the next round, akin to some ideas in Flashbots' SUAVE.
facts.context: Potential to innovate in transaction fee markets and MEV mitigation strategies.

facts.fact: A consensus upgrade to integrate DAGKNIGHT will require a new community grant request, similar to the previous Rust implementation upgrade.
facts.context: Community involvement and funding are necessary steps before development and deployment of this protocol upgrade.

facts.fact: As of the article, the DAGKNIGHT protocol pseudocode is inefficient and optimized for ease of reasoning (academic clarity), not for real-world implementation; efficient algorithms are pending.
facts.context: Substantial work is needed before DK can be deployed in mainnet use.

facts.fact: Michael Sutton, a core Kaspa developer, proposed a major refactoring of the Kaspad full-node codebase and rewriting it in Rust.
facts.context: The rewrite aims to achieve an order-of-magnitude enhancement in Kaspad full-node performance.

facts.fact: The current Kaspad full-node codebase is derived from btcd, the Bitcoin client, and is written in Golang.
facts.context: The adaptation introduces technical debt and code complexity that hinders new contributor onboarding.

facts.fact: The proposed refactor explicitly targets writing the new codebase to be modular and legible in addition to improving performance.
facts.context: A more modular and readable codebase will facilitate contributions and ongoing maintenance, not just speed improvements.

facts.fact: The current Kaspa community treasury is contribution-based and managed by a small group of volunteers.
facts.context: This affects the project's ability to fund large-scale development, including the proposed rewrite.

facts.fact: The random block reward in Kaspa has been removed and replaced with a deterministic block reward of 500 Kaspa per block.
facts.context: This change simplifies logic and debugging, ensuring a predictable daily emission of 43,200,000 Kaspa (86,400 blocks/day * 500 Kaspa).

facts.fact: A forthcoming rebase in Kaspa is described as cosmetic, involving a rename or altering representation, but will not affect proportional ownership.
facts.context: The rebase will not affect user balances or circulating supply distribution, easing concerns about possible loss or redistribution of holdings.

facts.fact: A deflationary monetary policy hard fork (HF) is planned for Kaspa, with full specification to be provided after the network stabilizes.
facts.context: This hard fork will introduce or clarify a deflationary mechanism in Kaspa's supply, affecting future monetary policy and emission rates.

facts.fact: During the post-crash recovery, developers did not consider a rollback to an earlier state, but instead sought the latest state with a valid UTXO commitment.
facts.context: This approach prioritized chain integrity and data accuracy, focusing on consistency of Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO) commitments for recovery.

facts.fact: Developers verified the correctness of the UTXO algebra by rebuilding state from datadirs and matching the resulting UTXO commitment hash to the latest block (“710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20”).
facts.context: Matching the UTXO commitment proved the data integrity of the network, showing that errors were due to memory problems and not DAG UTXO algebra flaws.

facts.fact: The existing architecture of the UTXO commitment module is acknowledged as needing revision for improved protection against database failures.
facts.context: Enhancing this module would strengthen network resilience to similar issues in the future.

facts.fact: Kaspa's monetary policy will be deflationary, with a halving schedule more aggressive than Bitcoin’s, and the details about activation timing and initial block reward are to be decided.
facts.context: The design of the monetary policy directly affects the network's inflation rate, token supply cap, and economic incentives.

facts.fact: Kaspa uses a PoW variant named "k-heavy-hash," which is based on "heavy-hash" and is intended to be CapEx-heavy.
facts.context: Choice of PoW algorithm affects network security, decentralization, miner incentive structure, and hardware requirements.

facts.fact: There will be a hard fork (HF) next week to fix a bug and decrease block header size.
facts.context: Hard forks introduce backward-incompatible changes, affecting node software and potentially miners, improving stability and efficiency.

facts.fact: There will be a subsequent hard fork in a few weeks to embed the planned monetary policy into the protocol.
facts.context: Integrating monetary policy at the protocol level ensures predictable economic behavior and trust in the system.

facts.fact: Current average block reward is approximately 500 Kaspa.
facts.context: The block reward size affects mining incentives and network security before policy changes.

facts.fact: The development team is small and mainly composed of people working part-time, some funded by DAGlabs but operating in a self-managed manner.
facts.context: Limited development resources can impact project agility, response to bugs, and new feature deployment.

facts.fact: There is no official project roadmap, but the stated priorities are to gradually accelerate block production to 10 blocks per second, then implement an upgraded consensus protocol, pending research.
facts.context: Network throughput and consensus mechanisms are foundational to the capability and scalability of a blockchain platform.

facts.fact: Community members are encouraged to assist in development, report bugs, add features, and participate in open-source collaboration; DAGlabs can fund additional self-managing developers.
facts.context: Community-driven development models can boost project sustainability and innovation if sufficient contributors engage.

facts.fact: Plans exist to deploy a block explorer next week.
facts.context: A block explorer greatly aids network usability and transparency for users and developers.

facts.fact: Users are permitted to stress test UTXO throughput at any time, but bug fix response may be delayed due to limited developer availability.
facts.context: Stress testing helps identify performance bottlenecks and bugs but effectiveness depends on development capacity to respond.

facts.fact: Kaspa will be launched initially in "gamenet mode," an experimental, research-oriented network distinct from traditional mainnets.
facts.context: The purpose is to facilitate experimentation and the study of cryptoeconomic attacks in a live environment prior to full mainnet launch.

facts.fact: Kaspa's initial network ("gamenet") will have deliberate fragility via a randomized, semi-scarce monetary policy.
facts.context: This design choice introduces unpredictable token supply characteristics to foster research and discourage early commercialization.

facts.fact: Gamenet will be a testing ground for reward-based and MEV-based blockchain reorg attacks.
facts.context: This allows direct simulation and analysis of miner extractable value (MEV) and reorganization dynamics in a live environment.

facts.fact: The initial mining algorithm proposed is Ethash, making it accessible to CPU and GPU miners.
facts.context: Ethash enables broader miner participation due to its hardware requirements.

facts.fact: Kaspa will initially lack EVM (Ethereum Virtual Machine) support.
facts.context: This limits compatibility with existing Ethereum-based applications and tools at launch.

facts.fact: Early-stage Kaspa tokens will be deliberately unfit for commercialization and exchange listing.
facts.context: This is intended to prevent early speculation and focus participation on research rather than immediate financial gain.

facts.fact: Block rewards in gamenet will incentivize real-world attack simulations, including selfish mining and reorg attacks.
facts.context: Such incentives are designed to rigorously test the resilience of the Kaspa DAG consensus protocol.

facts.fact: Gamenet 2.0 will require development of an Ethereum bridge to simulate and practice MEV reorgs across chains.
facts.context: An Ethereum bridge enables interoperability and more realistic MEV attack testing via cross-chain scenarios.

facts.fact: The long-term plan includes transitioning from gamenet to mainnet, with a switch to a solid monetary policy and full scarcity.
facts.context: This shift will retrospectively make early mining activity profitable, realigning incentives and supply for commercial activity.

facts.fact: The platform will act as a testbed for cryptography and MEV-related solutions proposed by external commercial L2 projects.
facts.context: Third-party projects can implement and test their MEV mitigation strategies in a live, hostile environment.

facts.fact: The article discusses SPV (Simplified Payment Verification) sync mode based on multiplicative-hash UTXO-commitments.
facts.context: Multiplicative-hash UTXO-commitments are mentioned as a basis for SPV sync mode; this suggests a technical approach allowing nodes to quickly sync and verify UTXOs without requiring the full historical blockchain, improving scalability.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The author asserts that verifying the proper functioning of all external systems one relies on is infeasible and unscalable, thus advocating for trust in system design over exhaustive user verification.
facts.context: This reflects a design philosophy in Kaspa and related technologies, determining user node verification strategies and network usability at scale.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The primary highlighted consensus system trait in the article is facilitating agreement (consensus), rather than enforcing historical consistency (full audit of all past transactions).
facts.context: This technical viewpoint shapes Kaspa’s and potentially other cryptocurrencies’ approach to node synchronization and network integrity—prioritizing economic majority agreement over guaranteed historical validity for every transaction.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Faster block times improve transaction confirmation times under the "block-based" security paradigm, where merchants wait for a sufficient number of blocks to confirm transactions.
facts.context: In this paradigm, increasing the block rate directly reduces the time merchants and users must wait for transaction finality, which improves user experience.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: There are two primary paradigms for transaction confirmation in cryptocurrency: (1) waiting for a sufficient number of blocks, and (2) waiting a fixed amount of absolute time.
facts.context: The effectiveness of faster block times in reducing confirmation time depends on which paradigm is used.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The effectiveness of accelerating block times in improving confirmation speed is only present if the confirmation paradigm is block-based rather than strictly time-based.
facts.context: If users or systems require a fixed time to confirmation regardless of block interval, increasing block frequency won't improve user-facing speed.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Bitcoin miners' security budget (mining revenue per hour, approx. several million USD/hour as of the article's writing) is much smaller in proportion to Bitcoin's market capitalization (several hundred billion USD).
facts.context: Highlights a fundamental security consideration for proof-of-work cryptocurrencies where security is ultimately limited by ongoing mining expenditure.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Attack models and settlement assurance in cryptocurrencies depend on both the length of the confirmation window (in blocks) and the economic model of an attacker's incentives and budget.
facts.context: The article draws a distinction between irreversibility achieved by waiting for blocks (chain depth) versus waiting for elapsed time, which reflects underlying attacker cost models.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: DAGlabs is a for-profit entity whose business model is based on mining Kaspa and is additionally funding many core Kaspa developers and researchers.
facts.context: This establishes DAGlabs’ central role in both technical development and mining at Kaspa’s outset.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Kaspa contains no premine or founders’ rewards.
facts.context: Ensures no initial token allocation advantage to founders or developers.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Kaspa is not attempting to be a “fair launch” coin, acknowledging the subjectivity of “fair” in cryptocurrency launches.
facts.context: Conceptually distinguishes Kaspa’s launch approach, affecting community expectations.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Kaspa is described as a “community launch” coin, with mechanisms intended to allow early members to secure allocation and benefit from low inflation rates.
facts.context: This informs Kaspa’s inflation and distribution strategy, focusing on community engagement.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Inflation parameters in Kaspa are planned to be adjustable according to the size of the community, as measured by some verifiable quantity.
facts.context: Dynamic inflation tuning aims to balance token supply with actual community scale.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The community-centric allocation mechanism is planned to be deployed by DAGlabs outside the core Kaspa protocol on a best-effort basis.
facts.context: Demonstrates separation between protocol rules and external allocation methods.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: DAGlabs will oversee a pre-launch customization of ASICs supporting a Kaspa-specific hash function, providing initial mining advantage.
facts.context: Custom ASICs give early miners (mainly DAGlabs) a start, influencing security and decentralization in early phases.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: These customized ASIC mining machines will dominate the Kaspa mining market for an unspecified period until broader competition arises.
facts.context: Early mining centralization may affect coin distribution and security.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The value of the customized ASICs is intended to be distributed among early contributors, investors, the community, and a development fund, potentially via an ASIC presale model.
facts.context: Suggests economic incentive structure focuses on early supporters and development sustainability.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: DAGlabs ruled out physical distribution/presale of ASICs due to cost, limited demand, and hardware not being user-friendly for home miners.
facts.context: Limits miner diversity at launch, impacting decentralization.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: DAGlabs intends to focus on geographically and politically distributing mining machines, and enabling economic participation of the community in mining.
facts.context: Efforts to mitigate early centralization and encourage broader participation.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The GHOST protocol is an alternative to Bitcoin’s longest-chain rule and uses proof of work embedded in off-chain blocks by traversing the tree structure formed by forks to select the main chain differently.
facts.context: GHOST was designed to allow for faster block times without suffering from orphan blocks and deteriorating security, directly addressing Bitcoin’s security-speed tradeoff.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The GHOST protocol selects the main chain by counting the number of blocks extending from a given block, rather than simply using the chain with the most blocks above it ("longest chain").
facts.context: This shift in chain selection reduces the negative impact of frequent forks and orphaning in high-speed block production.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: A variant of GHOST, called the Inclusive Blockchain Protocols, was proposed, introducing the concept of a blockDAG (directed acyclic graph structure for blocks).
facts.context: The blockDAG structure enables higher throughput and helps linearize block rewards across miners compared to traditional blockchain structures.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The blockDAG protocol focuses on increasing throughput for the same level of security, and was coauthored with Yoad Lewenberg.
facts.context: Enhancing throughput without reducing security is a major challenge in blockchain scalability.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: GHOST, as originally proposed, has a scaling limitation: its achievable throughput and block times are still fundamentally limited by network latency, similar to Bitcoin.
facts.context: This identifies a key drawback of GHOST, motivating further research into protocols that can further decouple speed from security constraints.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: PHANTOM is a protocol family based on blockDAGs, generalizing Nakamoto Consensus to support high block rates, including subsecond block times.
facts.context: PHANTOM extends the theoretical and practical scalability of proof-of-work chain selection beyond both Bitcoin and GHOST.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The PHANTOM protocol considers Nakamoto Consensus as the slowest member of its protocol family.
facts.context: This situates Bitcoin’s consensus mechanism as a baseline for further acceleration of block production.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The blockDAG paradigm has miners propagate and extend the entire history of blocks, with new blocks referencing all recent blocks, rather than only extending a single "winning" chain.
facts.context: This approach significantly increases the information available for chain selection, supporting greater throughput and resilience to forks.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Achieving fast confirmation times with high block rates can reduce the variance of block rewards and potentially mitigate the need for mining pools, promoting mining decentralization.
facts.context: Lower variance in rewards is a technical mechanism that promotes a more decentralized mining landscape.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Ethereum enables composability by allowing one smart contract to interact permissionlessly with any other deployed smart contract.
facts.context: This capability allows complex decentralized applications (dApps) and financial products to be built atop each other and interact without development coordination.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Ethereum combines open source shared functionality with Nakamoto Consensus to enable a shared, alterable global state.
facts.context: This combination allows multiple contracts and dApps to operate on a common blockchain ledger, providing predictable and coordinated interactions.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: The Ethereum blockchain allows synchronous composability, meaning transactions and smart contract function calls can occur and complete within the same transaction or block, maintaining atomicity.
facts.context: Synchronous composability guarantees that all changes in a contract interaction will happen together or not at all, which is critical for DeFi and complex dApp workflows.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Atomicity in Ethereum ensures that a set of events and consequences within a transaction will either all occur or none will, enabling predictable and reliable multi-contract interactions.
facts.context: This is a crucial property for decentralized finance (DeFi) where users and dApps rely on composite, multi-step financial transactions.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

facts.fact: Shared, synchronous state on Ethereum is an enabler for composable DeFi applications, separating it from simple open APIs or transparent, permissionless finance.
facts.context: This shared state allows for complex interactions, such as multi-step asset swaps or pooling, to be written and executed atomically on-chain.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

technical.fact: Kaspa’s architecture and execution, particularly by the Crescendo development team, achieves a 6000x improvement over Satoshi Nakamoto's original Bitcoin protocol while retaining the same trust model.
technical.context: Demonstrates a significant technical advancement over the original Bitcoin protocol, while upholding decentralized, trustless security assumptions.

technical.context: The adaptation introduces technical debt and code complexity that hinders new contributor onboarding.

technical.context: The design of the monetary policy directly affects the network's inflation rate, token supply cap, and economic incentives.

technical.context: The block reward size affects mining incentives and network security before policy changes.

technical.context: A block explorer greatly aids network usability and transparency for users and developers.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: Kaspa’s network structure remains center-less with network control delegated to an anonymous, competing set of miners.
consensus.context: Confirms adherence to a decentralized mining consensus, aligning with principles similar to those of Bitcoin.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

consensus.fact: Kaspa’s consensus layer is being optimized primarily for speed of confirmation, with secondary focuses on throughput capacity, decentralization, and downstream considerations like MEV (Miner Extractable Value) resistance.
consensus.context: Speed of confirmation is a critical performance metric and a core goal of Kaspa’s technological design.

consensus.fact: The DAGKNIGHT (DK) protocol was published by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Michal Sutton as a proof-of-work consensus protocol responsive to actual adversarial network latency while being resilient to 49% byzantine attackers.
consensus.context: DK is, to the authors’ knowledge, the first PoW protocol with these properties, improving security and latency responsiveness compared to prior protocols.

consensus.fact: DAGKNIGHT enables high blocks-per-second (bps) rates with much faster confirmation times than previous protocols like GHOSTDAG.
consensus.context: High bps with fast confirmations means increased throughput without the compromise on confirmation speed, significant for scaling performance.

consensus.fact: Increasing bps rates indefinitely under DK does not always reduce confirmation times because higher rates increase DAG width and block header size, potentially increasing relative latency.
consensus.context: There's a trade-off between bps rate and confirmation time due to network and protocol-level constraints.

consensus.fact: One research direction enabled by DK is supporting "flexcaps," i.e., blocks of different sizes and difficulties, originally proposed for Bitcoin; this helps allow higher throughput during peak demand and manage resource consumption better.
consensus.context: Flexcaps could allow more flexible, scalable network throughput, but require a consensus protocol like DK that tolerates variable DAG width.

consensus.fact: DK protocol uniquely operates without needing to predefine or strictly bound the DAG width and can handle fluctuating DAG width over short timespans.
consensus.context: This feature is essential for dynamic throughput and block size adaptation, which is not possible in some other protocols.

consensus.fact: DK’s consensus properties could facilitate richer transaction fee mechanisms, as many miners can create blocks in the next round, akin to some ideas in Flashbots' SUAVE.
consensus.context: Potential to innovate in transaction fee markets and MEV mitigation strategies.

consensus.fact: A deflationary monetary policy hard fork (HF) is planned for Kaspa, with full specification to be provided after the network stabilizes.
consensus.context: This hard fork will introduce or clarify a deflationary mechanism in Kaspa's supply, affecting future monetary policy and emission rates.

consensus.fact: There is no official project roadmap, but the stated priorities are to gradually accelerate block production to 10 blocks per second, then implement an upgraded consensus protocol, pending research.
consensus.context: Network throughput and consensus mechanisms are foundational to the capability and scalability of a blockchain platform.

consensus.fact: The primary highlighted consensus system trait in the article is facilitating agreement (consensus), rather than enforcing historical consistency (full audit of all past transactions).
consensus.context: This technical viewpoint shapes Kaspa’s and potentially other cryptocurrencies’ approach to node synchronization and network integrity—prioritizing economic majority agreement over guaranteed historical validity for every transaction.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

consensus.fact: Faster block times improve transaction confirmation times under the "block-based" security paradigm, where merchants wait for a sufficient number of blocks to confirm transactions.
consensus.context: In this paradigm, increasing the block rate directly reduces the time merchants and users must wait for transaction finality, which improves user experience.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

consensus.fact: There are two primary paradigms for transaction confirmation in cryptocurrency: (1) waiting for a sufficient number of blocks, and (2) waiting a fixed amount of absolute time.
consensus.context: The effectiveness of faster block times in reducing confirmation time depends on which paradigm is used.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

consensus.fact: The effectiveness of accelerating block times in improving confirmation speed is only present if the confirmation paradigm is block-based rather than strictly time-based.
consensus.context: If users or systems require a fixed time to confirmation regardless of block interval, increasing block frequency won't improve user-facing speed.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

consensus.fact: The GHOST protocol is an alternative to Bitcoin’s longest-chain rule and uses proof of work embedded in off-chain blocks by traversing the tree structure formed by forks to select the main chain differently.
consensus.context: GHOST was designed to allow for faster block times without suffering from orphan blocks and deteriorating security, directly addressing Bitcoin’s security-speed tradeoff.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: The GHOST protocol selects the main chain by counting the number of blocks extending from a given block, rather than simply using the chain with the most blocks above it ("longest chain").
consensus.context: This shift in chain selection reduces the negative impact of frequent forks and orphaning in high-speed block production.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: A variant of GHOST, called the Inclusive Blockchain Protocols, was proposed, introducing the concept of a blockDAG (directed acyclic graph structure for blocks).
consensus.context: The blockDAG structure enables higher throughput and helps linearize block rewards across miners compared to traditional blockchain structures.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: The blockDAG protocol focuses on increasing throughput for the same level of security, and was coauthored with Yoad Lewenberg.
consensus.context: Enhancing throughput without reducing security is a major challenge in blockchain scalability.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: GHOST, as originally proposed, has a scaling limitation: its achievable throughput and block times are still fundamentally limited by network latency, similar to Bitcoin.
consensus.context: This identifies a key drawback of GHOST, motivating further research into protocols that can further decouple speed from security constraints.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: PHANTOM is a protocol family based on blockDAGs, generalizing Nakamoto Consensus to support high block rates, including subsecond block times.
consensus.context: PHANTOM extends the theoretical and practical scalability of proof-of-work chain selection beyond both Bitcoin and GHOST.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: The PHANTOM protocol considers Nakamoto Consensus as the slowest member of its protocol family.
consensus.context: This situates Bitcoin’s consensus mechanism as a baseline for further acceleration of block production.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: The blockDAG paradigm has miners propagate and extend the entire history of blocks, with new blocks referencing all recent blocks, rather than only extending a single "winning" chain.
consensus.context: This approach significantly increases the information available for chain selection, supporting greater throughput and resilience to forks.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

consensus.fact: Ethereum combines open source shared functionality with Nakamoto Consensus to enable a shared, alterable global state.
consensus.context: This combination allows multiple contracts and dApps to operate on a common blockchain ledger, providing predictable and coordinated interactions.

source.title: In which we’ll bе reduced to a spectrum of gray*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

governance.fact: The Kaspa project emphasizes being "culturally open-source, practically center-less, constitutionally principled" as core to unlocking and recognizing its value.
governance.context: Highlights the project's philosophy regarding community-driven, decentralized governance, which could influence development and adoption.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

governance.fact: DAGKNIGHT implementation for Kaspa is being proposed for funding via a community grant of 70 million KAS, equivalent to approximately 0.5% of the circulating supply.
governance.context: The grant mechanism is the prevailing custom for funding major Kaspa development, as with a previous 100 MKAS grant (~1% supply).

governance.fact: The previous community-funded Kaspa development grant was 100 million KAS, about 1% of the token’s circulating supply at the time.
governance.context: Indicates community practice and precedent for denominating development grants in KAS tokens rather than fiat.

governance.fact: A consensus upgrade to integrate DAGKNIGHT will require a new community grant request, similar to the previous Rust implementation upgrade.
governance.context: Community involvement and funding are necessary steps before development and deployment of this protocol upgrade.

governance.fact: The current Kaspa community treasury is contribution-based and managed by a small group of volunteers.
governance.context: This affects the project's ability to fund large-scale development, including the proposed rewrite.

governance.fact: The development team is small and mainly composed of people working part-time, some funded by DAGlabs but operating in a self-managed manner.
governance.context: Limited development resources can impact project agility, response to bugs, and new feature deployment.

governance.fact: Community members are encouraged to assist in development, report bugs, add features, and participate in open-source collaboration; DAGlabs can fund additional self-managing developers.
governance.context: Community-driven development models can boost project sustainability and innovation if sufficient contributors engage.

governance.fact: Early-stage Kaspa tokens will be deliberately unfit for commercialization and exchange listing.
governance.context: This is intended to prevent early speculation and focus participation on research rather than immediate financial gain.

governance.fact: The long-term plan includes transitioning from gamenet to mainnet, with a switch to a solid monetary policy and full scarcity.
governance.context: This shift will retrospectively make early mining activity profitable, realigning incentives and supply for commercial activity.

governance.fact: Kaspa contains no premine or founders’ rewards.
governance.context: Ensures no initial token allocation advantage to founders or developers.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

governance.fact: Kaspa is not attempting to be a “fair launch” coin, acknowledging the subjectivity of “fair” in cryptocurrency launches.
governance.context: Conceptually distinguishes Kaspa’s launch approach, affecting community expectations.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining.fact: The future arrival of ASICs is anticipated for Kaspa mining, which will shift the ecosystem from primarily GPU mining to more capital expenditure (CapEx)-heavy operations.
mining.context: The transition to ASICs is expected to promote network maturity and enhance mining efficiency.

mining.fact: As of the article's writing, approximately 5.3% of the Kaspa network’s hash rate is “NiceHash-able,” meaning it can be rented via hashpower marketplaces like NiceHash.
mining.context: A lower NiceHash-able percentage indicates a less “liquid” market for hashpower rental, making the network more resistant to inexpensive 51% attacks.

mining.fact: CapEx-heavy mining (i.e., ASIC-based mining) is considered more energy efficient in that a smaller fraction of the network’s security budget is expended per block compared to GPU/OpEx-heavy models.
mining.context: Higher energy efficiency is increasingly important for Kaspa’s future, especially as block rewards diminish and for addressing concerns over mining-related waste.

mining.fact: The random block reward in Kaspa has been removed and replaced with a deterministic block reward of 500 Kaspa per block.
mining.context: This change simplifies logic and debugging, ensuring a predictable daily emission of 43,200,000 Kaspa (86,400 blocks/day * 500 Kaspa).

mining.fact: Kaspa uses a PoW variant named "k-heavy-hash," which is based on "heavy-hash" and is intended to be CapEx-heavy.
mining.context: Choice of PoW algorithm affects network security, decentralization, miner incentive structure, and hardware requirements.

mining.fact: The initial mining algorithm proposed is Ethash, making it accessible to CPU and GPU miners.
mining.context: Ethash enables broader miner participation due to its hardware requirements.

mining.fact: These customized ASIC mining machines will dominate the Kaspa mining market for an unspecified period until broader competition arises.
mining.context: Early mining centralization may affect coin distribution and security.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining.fact: DAGlabs ruled out physical distribution/presale of ASICs due to cost, limited demand, and hardware not being user-friendly for home miners.
mining.context: Limits miner diversity at launch, impacting decentralization.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining.fact: Achieving fast confirmation times with high block rates can reduce the variance of block rewards and potentially mitigate the need for mining pools, promoting mining decentralization.
mining.context: Lower variance in rewards is a technical mechanism that promotes a more decentralized mining landscape.

source.title: In which I run with the GHOSTs of my hometown*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

security.fact: Fast confirmation speeds in Kaspa’s protocol depend on an “illiquid” mining market, meaning it is difficult for attackers to temporarily rent significant hash power and execute 51% attacks.
security.context: Illiquidity increases network security and reduces vulnerability to attacks facilitated by hashpower rental.

security.fact: DK could enable stealth transactions (stealth txns) leveraging asynchrony from high bps to protect users from Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) attacks, particularly when smart contracts are implemented in Kaspa.
security.context: This offers a new privacy and anti-MEV mechanism that is tightly coupled to DK's consensus properties.

security.fact: During the post-crash recovery, developers did not consider a rollback to an earlier state, but instead sought the latest state with a valid UTXO commitment.
security.context: This approach prioritized chain integrity and data accuracy, focusing on consistency of Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO) commitments for recovery.

security.fact: Users are permitted to stress test UTXO throughput at any time, but bug fix response may be delayed due to limited developer availability.
security.context: Stress testing helps identify performance bottlenecks and bugs but effectiveness depends on development capacity to respond.

security.fact: Gamenet will be a testing ground for reward-based and MEV-based blockchain reorg attacks.
security.context: This allows direct simulation and analysis of miner extractable value (MEV) and reorganization dynamics in a live environment.

security.fact: Block rewards in gamenet will incentivize real-world attack simulations, including selfish mining and reorg attacks.
security.context: Such incentives are designed to rigorously test the resilience of the Kaspa DAG consensus protocol.

security.fact: The author asserts that verifying the proper functioning of all external systems one relies on is infeasible and unscalable, thus advocating for trust in system design over exhaustive user verification.
security.context: This reflects a design philosophy in Kaspa and related technologies, determining user node verification strategies and network usability at scale.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

security.fact: Bitcoin miners' security budget (mining revenue per hour, approx. several million USD/hour as of the article's writing) is much smaller in proportion to Bitcoin's market capitalization (several hundred billion USD).
security.context: Highlights a fundamental security consideration for proof-of-work cryptocurrencies where security is ultimately limited by ongoing mining expenditure.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

security.fact: Attack models and settlement assurance in cryptocurrencies depend on both the length of the confirmation window (in blocks) and the economic model of an attacker's incentives and budget.
security.context: The article draws a distinction between irreversibility achieved by waiting for blocks (chain depth) versus waiting for elapsed time, which reflects underlying attacker cost models.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

development.fact: DAGKNIGHT (DK) is a protocol developed by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Sutton, released as an academic effort tied to the Kaspa project, and its main development tasks are outlined in KIP #2.
development.context: DK is an important consensus extension for Kaspa, and KIP #2 specifies remaining tasks needed for its production-readiness.

development.fact: The implementation of DAGKNIGHT on Kaspa will proceed regardless of whether the grant is accepted, though timelines would be unspecified and progress may be slower without incentive.
development.context: Suggests ongoing commitment to DK integration, but highlights grant’s role in prioritizing and resourcing work.

development.fact: DAGKNIGHT is characterized as infrastructure-level development for Kaspa, not involving application-layer (e.g., smart contract) features.
development.context: Clarifies that DK’s impact is primarily to Kaspa’s consensus/infrastructure, not to user-facing dApps or smart contracts.

development.fact: KIP #2 provides a detailed list of technical tasks and requirements necessary to complete DAGKNIGHT’s implementation within Kaspa.
development.context: Specifies a concrete source (https://github.com/kaspanet/kips/blob/master/kip-0002.md) for tracking DK development progress and required work.

development.fact: Further development on DAGKNIGHT is required for Kaspa, including completing the theoretical proof section, preparing the protocol for peer-review, devising efficient algorithms, and adapting to requirements such as minting, difficulty adjustment, and pruning.
development.context: These steps are necessary for practical implementation in a live cryptocurrency system; DK is not yet production-ready.

development.fact: As of the article, the DAGKNIGHT protocol pseudocode is inefficient and optimized for ease of reasoning (academic clarity), not for real-world implementation; efficient algorithms are pending.
development.context: Substantial work is needed before DK can be deployed in mainnet use.

development.fact: Michael Sutton, a core Kaspa developer, proposed a major refactoring of the Kaspad full-node codebase and rewriting it in Rust.
development.context: The rewrite aims to achieve an order-of-magnitude enhancement in Kaspad full-node performance.

development.fact: The proposed refactor explicitly targets writing the new codebase to be modular and legible in addition to improving performance.
development.context: A more modular and readable codebase will facilitate contributions and ongoing maintenance, not just speed improvements.

development.fact: A forthcoming rebase in Kaspa is described as cosmetic, involving a rename or altering representation, but will not affect proportional ownership.
development.context: The rebase will not affect user balances or circulating supply distribution, easing concerns about possible loss or redistribution of holdings.

development.fact: Developers verified the correctness of the UTXO algebra by rebuilding state from datadirs and matching the resulting UTXO commitment hash to the latest block (“710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20”).
development.context: Matching the UTXO commitment proved the data integrity of the network, showing that errors were due to memory problems and not DAG UTXO algebra flaws.

development.fact: The existing architecture of the UTXO commitment module is acknowledged as needing revision for improved protection against database failures.
development.context: Enhancing this module would strengthen network resilience to similar issues in the future.

development.fact: There will be a hard fork (HF) next week to fix a bug and decrease block header size.
development.context: Hard forks introduce backward-incompatible changes, affecting node software and potentially miners, improving stability and efficiency.

development.fact: There will be a subsequent hard fork in a few weeks to embed the planned monetary policy into the protocol.
development.context: Integrating monetary policy at the protocol level ensures predictable economic behavior and trust in the system.

development.fact: Kaspa will be launched initially in "gamenet mode," an experimental, research-oriented network distinct from traditional mainnets.
development.context: The purpose is to facilitate experimentation and the study of cryptoeconomic attacks in a live environment prior to full mainnet launch.

development.fact: Gamenet 2.0 will require development of an Ethereum bridge to simulate and practice MEV reorgs across chains.
development.context: An Ethereum bridge enables interoperability and more realistic MEV attack testing via cross-chain scenarios.

development.fact: The platform will act as a testbed for cryptography and MEV-related solutions proposed by external commercial L2 projects.
development.context: Third-party projects can implement and test their MEV mitigation strategies in a live, hostile environment.

development | mining.fact: DAGlabs is a for-profit entity whose business model is based on mining Kaspa and is additionally funding many core Kaspa developers and researchers.
development | mining.context: This establishes DAGlabs’ central role in both technical development and mining at Kaspa’s outset.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

governance | economic.fact: Kaspa is described as a “community launch” coin, with mechanisms intended to allow early members to secure allocation and benefit from low inflation rates.
governance | economic.context: This informs Kaspa’s inflation and distribution strategy, focusing on community engagement.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

economic | protocol.fact: Inflation parameters in Kaspa are planned to be adjustable according to the size of the community, as measured by some verifiable quantity.
economic | protocol.context: Dynamic inflation tuning aims to balance token supply with actual community scale.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

governance | development.fact: The community-centric allocation mechanism is planned to be deployed by DAGlabs outside the core Kaspa protocol on a best-effort basis.
governance | development.context: Demonstrates separation between protocol rules and external allocation methods.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining | security.fact: DAGlabs will oversee a pre-launch customization of ASICs supporting a Kaspa-specific hash function, providing initial mining advantage.
mining | security.context: Custom ASICs give early miners (mainly DAGlabs) a start, influencing security and decentralization in early phases.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining | economic | development.fact: The value of the customized ASICs is intended to be distributed among early contributors, investors, the community, and a development fund, potentially via an ASIC presale model.
mining | economic | development.context: Suggests economic incentive structure focuses on early supporters and development sustainability.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com

mining | governance.fact: DAGlabs intends to focus on geographically and politically distributing mining machines, and enabling economic participation of the community in mining.
mining | governance.context: Efforts to mitigate early centralization and encourage broader participation.

source.title: In which I love my truly, truly fair*
source.author: https://hashdag.medium.com
